negotiation_message:
Alice said in round 1: Hi Alfonso, based on the items and their values to me, I propose the following deal:
You take the 2 books, and I will take the 1 hat and 2 balls. 

This deal would give me a total value of 10 (4 for the hat + 3 for each of the 2 balls). 

I believe this deal is fair and envy-free, since the books have no value to me but likely have value to you. It's also Pareto optimal, as there is no other allocation that would make one of us better off without making the other worse off.

Let me know what you think of this proposed split of the items. I'm open to discussing further to find an agreement we are both satisfied with.
alfonso replied in round 1: Hi, if I agree on that deal, you will end up getting more points than me, I

Alice said in round 2: I appreciate you considering my initial proposal. You raise a fair point that my proposed split would result in me gaining more total value than you. To make the deal more balanced and envy-free, what if we modify it as follows:

I take the 1 hat (value 4 to me) and 1 ball (value 3), for a total of 7. 
You take the 2 books and the other ball. 

This way, the total value is more evenly split between us. I'm not sure what the item values are to you, but assuming the books have some value, this allocation should get us closer to an equal division while still being Pareto optimal.

I'm definitely open to discussion and want to find an agreement we both feel good about. What do you think of this modification to the deal? Let me know if you have any other suggestions.

Alice said in round 3: To summarize, I will take 1 hat and 1 ball, and you will take the 2 books and 1 ball. I'm satisfied with this as it feels like a balanced split given what we know about the item values to me. If you're in agreement, then I'm happy to confirm this deal and conclude our negotiation.
alfonso replied in round 3: halt negotiation
